quote: So many new faces. Students from India who have never been at a Halloween party, newcomer families came with their children. It was very noisy but we all found ways to talk to each other and laugh together.
Everyone had a wish to share! There were many families from Bhutan and the kids and adults who are still learning English wrote their wishes and hung them on the tree too!
Life's better working together! We are having our meetings during winter not in the community room but in the lobby of the building where one of our members live who uses wheelchair.
Thanks to the generous prize from the Early Bird Draw, Colin was able to do his own shopping in preparation for his snack bar!  Having treats-a-plenty meant that many guests opted to stay.

We love people using the park in fun, family friendly, inclusive ways, especially after dark. We believe one of the best ways to challenge any negative conceptions of the park after dark is to have people actually be in the park after dark. We had approximately double the number of pumpkins this year which was great. We hope to continue to grow this event in the future.

We of course strive to make all of our events inclusive, environmentally friendly, and promote safety but this event really sought to celebrate the history of our neighbourhood. We sought out local neighbourhood historians to research and present neighbourhood-specific questions for our trivia, our prizes included historical neighbourhood maps and Victoria Park mug. We ensured that we also had a round of trivia just for the kids to include them in the evening.

The BCA is proud of this event as it is family oriented, inclusive to all ages, heritages and offered as a result of a collaboration with the Lions, Brownies, Bridgeport Quilters and the Bridgeport Men’s Coffee Group.

A day with something for everyone in the community, including a skating party, short animated movies and winter crafts. Everyone was welcome to join in the activities offered for Family Day to connect with their family members and other residents in the neighbourhood.

activity: Unveiling of the Wilson Pool Mural and Holiday Party

quote: Just by helping neighbours connect on a deeper level than a simple hello from across the driveway or street.

These types of events help neighbours connect in ways more than a simple hello. We get to chat as we we all walk together, from house to house. We meet the newest neighbours this way as it tends to be a 'non intimidating' event that is easy for people to join in and leave as they feel comfortable. Plus the kids just enjoy all getting together for a fun activity right in their front yards.

activity: 6th annual Tremaine Park Easter Egg Hunt
quote: The highlight for me every year - is seeing how excited the big kids always are to take on the task of hiding the Eggs for the younger kids that have their hunt first.
We invited persons using the wheelchair or having mobility issues to come and enjoy being with the neighbours or help with taking participants names, giving out bags and gloves, etc.
We met at Alpine Public School and cleaned up in the nearby park (forest) and under the power line corridor. Some people cleaned up along the side of the street.
Helped to keep the park clean and raise awareness about continuing to make choices that help keep the park that way.
Connecting with neighbours in a friendly and welcoming attitude

It was a great meeting point for new people to the neighbourhood. One family reported seeing the poster the day after they moved in and so were excited to "meet" people within a week of living in the community!
This event was open to residents of all ages including adults and children and held in a community center for accessibility purposes.
All residents of all ages were encouraged to participate in the annual Easter Egg hunt
We included breakfast during this event and the teenagers that attended were quite excited about the breakfast and they sure cleaned up all the food!

This year's theme was "Get Active" and we had great representation from the Fire Department, local Martial Arts businesses and local vendors that are residents of Settler's Grove.  We even had a huge Bouncy Castle for children to enjoy; an organized Ball Hockey tournament and water balloon fights!

activity: Neighbours Day Party in the Park
Dogs of the East Ward, Canada 150 Celebration
quote: It brought together a lot of people who share a common interest. There were a number of people who don't have dogs who came out to see the dogs and enjoy the activities, and they enjoyed meeting other neighbours.

We envision an inclusive community that values human dignity, promotes wellbeing, with  belief that whole world is one family (Vasudaiva kutumbakam) so May all be happy; May all be free from sickness; (Sarve Bhavantu Sukhinah; Sarve Santu Niramaya).
Neighbours met in an organic way, which we hope will lead to goodwill and co-operation.
Many of the people have talked on Facebook for years, but now people can meet face to face and connect with each other!

It makes me excited to see kids that don't necessarily play together all of the time to still be able to get together and have a good night. Same goes for the potluck. We are all friendly, but I don't have big conversations with a lot of these neighbours on a day to day basis but at the potluck I do!
We are inclusive in that everyone is always welcome to both events. There were neighbours of all ages, ethnicities, abilities.
Afternoon movies are a great way to spend the afternoon. All are invited to attend, regardless of age, ethnicity to come out and watch the BCA newest movie pick.

The Guided Bird Watching Hike added to encourage community members and bird lovers to learn about the birds that call Bridgeport and the surrounding area home.
Highlighting Bridgeport Heritage on this fun-fact based tour of the community.
Encourage community members to join in to help keep Bridgeport beautiful.
The BCA AGM is held to inform community members of our efforts and future plans as well as BCA's financial position.
Many neighbours coming together in one place to get to know each other by name.  Kids having fun playing and interacting.

There is a sense of inclusion and community when you can walk through the neighbourhood and know all of the neighbours by first name and know a little about each of them. These events help strengthen those connections.

We wanted neighbours to meet other neighbours to create a safer community where people know each other. This was part of the reason we facilitated the "meet your neighbour" bingo. We believe people are safer when they're known by each other.
We had people come out with wheelchairs and walkers.We had corn with OR without butter. We had Halal hot dogs and vegetarian hotdogs.We had games for kids and adults plus bingo for all.
It was wonderful to see everyone in our small community come together and everyone helping out; to make it fantastic for the kids and adults.
The Annual BBQ is a good way to reconnect with neighbours at the end of the summer and a nice ending to summer.  It's nice to catch up with neighbours....

We liked that it encourages connections between neighbours through sharing of resources (plants). It is also a 'green' event in that it encourages people to share their extras and/or use existing materials rather than purchasing new ones.

Grade 5-6 students organized the WT Townshend Annual Laurentian Wetlands Cleanup. Participants picked up garbage on the school grounds and in the Wetlands that are located behind the school! Participants also added mulch to garden beds, trees and the natural playground.

Our Parent Council received a grant from Seeds of Diversity to build 2 raised garden beds in the school yard at WT Townshend. A group of volunteers came together to build the garden beds and fill with soil. We also added soil to smaller garden beds that did not have any soil.
Neighbours got to know each other more and feel that they all belong to this neighborhood.

The Valko Team -Dominion Lending Centres, sponsored an entire day and evening of activities for everyone in our neighbourhood!  It started with a neighbourhood garage sale, starting at 8am, followed by activities in the park, including fire trucks and a visit from the Kitchener United FC team, and ended with an outdoor showing of Sing in the Max Becker Common!

PVD was designed to celebrate the stories of neighbourhood residents and to bridge the gap between professional art and everyday people. Taking dance out of the theatre and into our daily lives, Porch View Dances engages real people in real spaces, making dance accessible to the families who perform in it, as well as the audience members who come to watch. It is in this way that PVD sends the strong and powerful message that art is for everyone.​

Every individual who was at the centre on this day was encouraged to eat, learn and meet their neighbours.  Staff and volunteers would approach each person with a smile and encourage them to take part.  We cooked a variety of different foods in our Cob oven so that there would be food available for several dietary restrictions and ethnic cultures.  We provided an inviting and inclusive atmosphere where everyone is welcome.

Acknowledged each person's strengths and value.  Listened to everyone's ideas.  Regardless of age, ability, religion, background we treat every individual with respect.  At our Lasagna build we had volunteers of all ages, abilities and backgrounds.  Everyone was given a task they felt comfortable performing.

The environment at the community garden is lovely, with greenery. We also had several people attend who had seen the advertisements on the chalkboards who had not attended previous events in the neighbourhood - the chalkboards had just been built so it was great to see that they are effective.

We had one potluck that included the family that had grown up in a house on Guelph St in the 50s and 60s, and the park was their backyard. It was great to learn about the park and the neighbourhood and how it has changed. We also made sure the potlucks were low-waste.

activity: Homewood Green Art Wall Installation Weekend
quote: Everyone got together on a very hot weekend and put some serious manual labour into making our neighbourhood a beautiful place.
The kids didn't care that it was only a couple of degrees at night. They were just happy to enjoy nature.

People were able to see how Diwali is celebrated. Knowing more about each other's cultures brings us together. Our youth played an active role to get a by- law changed to have fireworks for Diwali in the city of Kitchener for the first time.

We loved having people from very diverse backgrounds. Our cafe was a great hit. People spent some quality time eating and chatting with their friends and neighbours there. They did not want to leave even when the event was over.

Our community partners and volunteers were not from the same faith group as the celebrating community. It showed a greater sense of community and connections. Muslims from very different cultural backgrounds were in attendance.

activity: Neighbours Day Community Garage Sale/Lite Festival
quote: We had a kite festival in our neighbourhood for the first time. There was something for everyone to attract them to the event.
Sort of -- children led initiative to raise money for the Canada Day bouncy castle through selling lemonade, cookies, crafts and artwork. Around a dozen children all worked together on this.

We are starting to see more and more residents planting gardens and planting on boulevards. We believe this is largely in part to exchanging tips about gardening at this swap and making a large variety of plants available at little or no cost.
Bring yourself, bring your neighbours, and bring your enthusiasm to our General Meeting!

I am always excited to see the kids and how they react as they realize they get a whole afternoon of activities, games, food as fun, as much as they want until it's over or mom and dad say enough /times up. I like to see the volunteers and our participants interacting with people from the neighborhood.
It's the friendly atmosphere, seeing everyone work toward a common goal of keeping our community clean, safe and appealing. To see the amount of ewaste kept out of the landfills.

Many families participated and came together for a fun morning, SO many participants and energy levels high. Giant parades of kids running through the neighbourhood on the egg hunt. Nice to see the big kids helping out the wee ones
Seeing the swarms of families make the parade through the hood to all meet up in the park.

We had a fun multi-generational event, where kids played, people laughed and people volunteered. It was especially amazing this year with the residents bringing some of their own ideas and executing, like henna, face painting and barbequed Corn.
